biz.gabrys.easybundle

Class PropertyResourceBundleFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • biz.gabrys.easybundle.PropertyResourceBundleFactory
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    BundleFactory

    public class PropertyResourceBundleFactory
extends Object
implements BundleFactory

    Standard implementation of BundleFactory which store translations in "one" property file (one for all bundles). The path to the property file must be the same as the file path prefix plus additional information about locale. Correct hierarchy of file names:

    1. fileName_language_country_variant.properties
    2. fileName_language_country.properties
    3. fileName_language.properties
    4. fileName.properties

    Example: file path prefix is equal directory/languages.

    • directory/languages_pl_PL_WINDOWS.properties
    • directory/languages_pl_PL.properties
    • directory/languages_pl.properties
    • directory/languages.properties

    The content of the property file should have the following structure: 

     #comment are available
 interfaceName1.key1=value1
 interfaceName1.key2=value2
 interfaceName2.key1=value3

    *InterfaceName means package name plus class name, e.g. org.example.Messages.

    Example: 

     org.example.Messages.title=Bundle Factory 
 org.example.Messages.topic=How to create property file
 #comment
 org.example.Copyright.information=Copyright@ 2013, All rights Reserved

    How to use the factory: 

     package org.example;
 
 public interface Messages {
  
      String getTitle();
      
      String getTopic();
 }
 
 public interface Copyright {
  
      String getInformation();
 }
 
 final String filePathPrefix = "directory/languages";
 final BundleFactory factory = new PropertyResourceBundleFactory(filePathPrefix);
 final Messages messagesBundle =
  (Messages) factory.create(Messages.class, Locale.getDefault());
 final Copyright copyrightBundle =
  (Copyright) factory.create(Copyright.class, Locale.getDefault());
 System.out.println(bundle.getTitle());
 System.out.println(bundle.getTopic());
 System.out.println(bundle.getCopyrightInformation());

    will return: 

     Bundle Factory
 How to create property file
 Copyright@ 2013, All rights Reserved

    The factory creates a hierarchy of bundles which allows the sharing of values. This functionality will be presented on the following example.

    Example: An user defined two bundles languages.properties and languages_pl.properties. The files content is equal:

    • languages.properties: 
       org.example.Messages.name=Name
 org.example.Messages.topic=default
    • languages_pl.properties: 
       org.example.Messages.name=Nazwa
 #org.example.Messages is undefined

    When the user will execute the following code: 

     final String filePathPrefix = "directory/languages";
 final BundleFactory factory = new PropertyResourceBundleFactory(filePathPrefix);
 Messages bundle = (Messages) factory.create(Messages.class, Locale.ENGLISH);
 System.out.println(bundle.getName());
 System.out.println(bundle.getTopic());
 bundle = (Messages) factory.create(Messages.class, new Locale("pl"));
 System.out.println(bundle.getName());
 System.out.println(bundle.getTopic());

    He will get the following results: 

     Name
 default
 Nazwa
 default
    Since:
    1.0
    See Also:
    BundleValidator, MultiplePropertyResourceBundleFactory
